title: Missing Password Confirmation at a Critical Function (Payout Method)

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hey Hackerone Team,

Payout being one the very important matter demands to be taken extra precaution. But at our lovable platform "Hackerone" there is no Password Confirmation at one of very critical functions i.e Payout Method/state Change.
All the other important functions like : 1.) Email Change 2.) Password Change 3.) Disable Account are additionally protected by demanding the user to enter his current password to make any changes in them. 

But to my dismay Payout Method requires no additional authorization to:
 1.) Change state of any payout method, 2.) Add new payout method or 3.) Delete any. 

Which is quite unexpected. Isn't it? 
Or shall we not consider this function critical enough (like email,password change etc.) to demand additional security practice?

Proof Of Concept:
STEP 1.) Visit the following link with a logged in researcher account:
              https://hackerone.com/settings/payment_preferences

STEP 2.) Make any changes there. Notice you won't be asked to re-enter your password.


Very keen to have your response
Himanshu Kumar

## Impact

All the critical functionalities are protected by issuing a password confirmation as an additional security practice so that even if some one gets access to some logged in session, they can't do much harm. This certainly is just a best practice to cover any unintended mistakes of some worthy users.

The issue is one the missing best practices like the following other reports:
https://hackerone.com/reports/242964
https://hackerone.com/reports/546
https://hackerone.com/reports/38343

activities.message: Hi @hk755a - thanks for the report. We're closing this behavior as an accepted risk. The audience this would vulnerability typically affect (hackers) are already security-minded and likely to have very strong security settings on their account (long, randomly generated password and 2FA for example) making an account takeover near impossible. We might change this in the future, but are fine with the behavior for the time being. Thanks again for letting us know, but this is not something we're prioritizing right now. Happy hacking!

Hey @jobert 
Very thankful for such a quick response.

I am sure you may close this as accepted risk as this was anyway a security best practice only. But few things come to my mind here:
1.) Not Everyone has the 2FA option. 
2.) As human beings, we hackers may also perform some mistakes, like leaving an open session on some organisational public computer. ( This certainly does not require the attacker to takeover the account password)

The risk may be low but still hackerone may save its users even if they somehow have just in case unintentionally forgotten to log themselves out. 

Its just an additional security measure for a very critical function as you may understand. BTW it was really nice having the co-founder responding on such a issue. :)

> 1.) Not Everyone has the 2FA option. 

We're planning to roll that out in the near future!

> As human beings, we hackers may also perform some mistakes, like leaving an open session on some organisational public computer. ( This certainly does not require the attacker to takeover the account password)

That's absolutely true, but I'd like to point out [Immutable Law of Security #3](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc722487.aspx#EIAA): If a bad guy has unrestricted physical access to your computer, it's not your computer anymore.

We might do something about this in the future, it's just not a priority for us right now. Thanks again, it's appreciated. Happy hacking!

@jobert 
I am looking forward for the 2FA as i don't have it currently.

Yes i agree with the law you mentioned. Hackerone has additional protection all over the site APART FROM THIS ONE SINGLE FUNCTION. This din't seem to me  to be up to the standard of security of this platform so thought to notify you guys. 

I am sorry if i am extending this further But by the "Law Of Averages" a few of our fellow hackerone users who usually accesses hackerone from public computers might sometimes forget to log themselves out.

@hk755a We'll get to in time. It's not an invalid find, but it doesn't pose an immediate risk for our systems right now. Users that care about their security will pay attention to this. Also, we have a low session timeout that'll lower the risk of people finding signed in sessions. This timeout is increased when they've used the "Remember me" function, but that's the user's own decision and not enabled by default.

@jobert 
Yes I completely agree with you that this issue doesn't necessarily demand an immediate fix. 

But yes we all shall agree that it would have been better to treat this function also as important as the other functions are being treated (for example- email,password change), As this itself is highly critical function for all the obvious reasons.
I have observed similar sites like bugcrowd, facebook, twitter all requiring additional authorization for all the important/critical functions.
Now, I completely leave up to you to decide if this needs to be changed, As you are the final decision maker.

Thanks. It's always lovely to interact with any of hackerone team!

@jobert 
If you don't mind, Shall we disclose this?
